thread.title: General Motors, Google, and Amazon: Doug Kass' Views
thread.title_full: General Motors, Google, and Amazon: Doug Kass' Views

title: General Motors, Google, and Amazon: Doug Kass' Views
text:
My cautious view on gold was highlighted last week and on numerous times earlier. 
For that matter, the broad drop in the price of many commodities has continued -- oil, steel, copper and so forth. 
It's not only gold bugs who are worried, as many countries and regions are commodities-dependent . Position: None 
GM Driving to Higher Ground Originally published at 10:17 A.M. EDT on July 23, 2015 
Do wonders never cease? 
The inexorable share price decline of General Motors ( GM - Get Report ) should now be stemmed after this morning's solid beat. 
Adjusted earnings per share of $1.29 were 20 cents better than consensus expectations principally due to strength in North America. 
Equally important, EBIT came in at $2.9 billion, which was $500 million ahead of forecasts, and operating margins set a company record at 7.5%. Imagine what would happen if Europe improved! 
Citing an expected second-half improvement in profits and cash flow, GM sees sustainable China joint venture profits, which have been a question mark moving forward. 
I see a steady improvement in the company's return on capital and profits in 2016, with EPS close to $5.75, which would be well ahead of this year's estimate of $4.60 per share. 
With an historically low valuation of less than 6x next year, a dividend yield of 4.7% and a free cash flow yield estimated at above 15% for 2016, I am sticking with this undervalued stock, which seems to be more than discounting "peak autos." 
I have been a consistent buyer of GM on the recent weakness and will add with a limit at $31.75 today. (I just added!) Position: Long GM
